awd_titl_txt: Measuring Student Engagement in Lower Division Engineering Mathematics Classes
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by improving undergraduate engineering education.  It will do so by designing, implementing, and testing a system to measure engineering students' emotional, behavioral, and cognitive engagement in first- and second-year engineering mathematics classes. Engineering programs suffer from a high rate of attrition in the freshman year, primarily due to poor engagement of students with their classes. The project plans to develop a sensor-driven, computational approach to measure emotional and behavioral components of student engagement.  This information will be used to identify teaching strategies that increase engagement, with the goal of enhancing student success and retention in STEM education pathways. The project features a multi-disciplinary collaboration between faculty and undergraduate researchers in engineering, the physical sciences, psychological sciences, and education. The project will involve approximately 300 students in first- and second-year engineering mathematics classes and the experienced faculty who teach these courses. Findings from the project could be a valuable step toward an early warning system to detect student disengagement and anxiety in STEM and non-STEM courses.  

Project goals include: (i) establishment of a robust network of non-obtrusive and non-invasive sensors in mid-size classes to enable real-time extraction of facial and vital signs, which will be integrated and displayed on instructors' dashboards; (ii) identification of robust descriptors for modeling the emotional and behavioral components of engagement using data collected by the sensor networks; (iii)  pilot testing of  the system's effectiveness in gathering meaningful data for subsequent work on emotional, behavioral, and cognitive metrics of engagement. The fundamental research question to be addressed relates to improving student learning by the automated capture of non-verbal cues of engagement:  How can we use students' expressions of engagement, based on non-verbal signs such as facial expressions, body and eye movements, physiological reactions, posture, to enhance learning? Findings from the project will constitute a foundation for multi-disciplinary research to incorporate novel machine learning and artificial intelligence-based models for measuring engagement in STEM classes. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Project 1900456 “Measuring Student Engagement in Lower Division Engineering Mathematics Classes”, June 2019 – June 2022 aimed to develop a sensor-driven, computational approach to measure emotional and behavioral components of students’ engagement in early STEM engineering classwork.

The project endured the COVID19 outbreak in late 2019 and throughout 2020 and middle of 2021 when classes were forced to be online.

The project created an agenda for research on the vital subject of student engagement which has been correlated with students’ performance in courses, and the high rate of attrition of students due to early engineering course work which covers background in mathematics, physics and chemistry as prelude to engineering subjects. The subject of engagement cuts across various disciplines and the research team included faculty in education and psychology in addition to engineering. A major challenge has been developing data acquisition setup that is non-intrusive, flexible, non-stigmatizing, and easy to maintain, and conforming with university approved IRB.  

Major accomplishments of the project include: : a) constructing a novel platform for in-class measurements of behavioral and emotional engagements, tested in a small-size STEM classroom; b) establishing a robust protocol for student participation, approved by an IRB, ensuring highest standard of incorporation of the platform for STEM coursework without coercion or stigmatization based on race, ethnicity, or gender; c) creating a multidisciplinary team of researchers with the expertise to design, test, and validate quantifiable engagement measures for students in early STEM engineering coursework; d) securing major support from the university administration for this initiative, including redesigning classroom settings, purchasing hardware, and guaranteeing technical support. The technical discoveries so far have been reported in four technical publications and the dissertation of a PhD student.

Extensions underway include: 1) incorporating educational paradigms that invoke cognitive responses during the course delivery; 2) establishing robust teacher dashboards that enable real-time reading of students’ engagement regardless of the class sitting and the number of students; and 3) establishing novel AI-based methodologies to enhance course delivery and increase students’ engagements.
